title: Did Johnny Cash ever have a number one hit? - Quora

response.answer_text: Although he is in the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, Johnny Cash never achieved a number 1 hit on the Hot 100 Singles Chart. His biggest pop hit was A Boy Named Sue, which reached number 2 in 1969.  However, on the Billboard Hot Country Singles Chart, he managed 14 number 1 hits. He collected five in the 1950s: I Walk the Line and There You Go (both in 1956), Ballad of a Teenage Queen, Guess Things Happen that Way, and Don’t Take Your Guns to Town (all three in 1958). He collected a total of 19 top ten country hits in the decade. Moving on the 1960s, Johnny Cash again reached the top five times: Ring of Fire (in 1963), Understand Your Man (in 1964), Folsom Prison Blues - Live and Daddy Sang Bass (both in 1968), and A Boy Named Sue (in 1969). He added 16 more top ten country hits to his total in this decade. There were three number 1 hits in the 1970s: Sunday Mornin’ Comin’ Down - Live and Flesh and Blood (both in 1970), along with One Piece at a Time (in 1976). He garnered 10 top ten country hits in the decade. Johnny Cash had only one number 1 hit in the 1980s: Highwayman (in 1985) as a member of the country supergroup the Highwaymen (with Waylon Jennings, Willie Nelson & Kris Kristofferson). His only other top ten country hit in the decade was The Baron (in 1981). In addition to these totals, Johnny Cash added four top tens in duets with his wife, June Carter, and one more with Waylon Jennings. So the grand totals are 14 number 1 hits, along with 52 top ten hits — all on the Billboard Hot Country Singles Chart. I’d say he deserves his place in both the Rock & Roll and Country Music halls of fame.

According to Billboard - Music Charts, News, Photos & Video Johnny Cash had five number one hits between 1959(Dont take your guns to town) and 1969. Ring of Fire, Folsom Prison Blues, Daddy Sang Bass and Understand your man. He had many more in the top ten over his career. He was a great song writer and singer.

In the UK, the answer is, unfortunately not. The best he got were two No4 hits. First in September 1969 with  "A Boy Named Sue", and then in April 1972, with the the help of The Evangel Temple Choir, he reached the same spot with  "A Thing Called Love". It's extremely sad that his final recording  "Hurt" barely got into the Top Forty, stalling at No39.

None, on the Billboard pop charts. His biggest single there, “A Boy Named Sue,” only reached #2. He had several songs that reached #1 on the country charts, including “I Walk the Line,” “I Guess Things Happen That Way,” and “Don’t Take Your Guns to Town.”

He had fourteen #1s on the Billboard Hot Country chart, but his peak on the Hot 100 was #2 for A Boy Named Sue in August of 1969. He placed two other songs in the top 20: Ring of Fire (1963) hit #17 and What is Truth (1970) reached #19.
